content.description: Start climbing at the thin crack to the first bolt on low angled, decent rock.  After the first bolt, the rock is great.  Continue another bolt to the steep section.  Climb up on face holds below the bulge.  There, either climb straight up between the bulges, then left, or under the left  bulge, then up to the anchors.
content.protection: 5 bolts, gear to 1".  2 bolt anchor.  Rap or maybe lower if the anchors are right, I don't remember.
content.location: At the right end of the Wall of the Unclimbables, this is the bolted line up the steep face, topping out in the groove at the top.

content.description: Surmount the fist/offwith roof halfway up and easier ground to the top.  Good rock.
content.protection: Pro to the offwidth stuff.  Rap off trees or any top accessible anchors.
content.location: Near the middle of the Wall of the Unclimbables area, just right around the corner from Last Chance in the small alcove.  This is the fist/offwidth roof crack.

content.description: To the Right of "Twister" and left of "Take the Skinheads Bowling" on a blank, but plated face beneath a bulge with a fingercrack in it.
content.protection: Creative.  Both cruxes take some ingenuity to protect, plus a very slim sling, and a very tiny cam. Bolted Anchors.

content.description:
Climb the slab (a little lichen) 15 feet to a small ledge.  Follow the slab dihedral feature to the top. 

  Walkoff back towards the dog walkdown on a narrow ledge.
content.protection: Very little, if any pro available.  You would also have to walk back from the edge a bit at the top to find an anchor or use a tree.
content.location: This is the first route in the Outback.  It is the slab facing the dog walkdown and starts about 10 feet right of the corner.
between Dike Brigade and Top Sider

content.description: Climb the low-angled groove to the U-shaped roof.  Pull the small roof and climb the face to the anchors.  Be careful of the holds near the top.  They look great, but one pulled off in my hands at the anchor, causing me to suggest a new rating of 5.9+, instead of the former 5.9.  Great climbing, though.
content.protection: Gear to 1", 2-bolt anchor.  Rap or lower.
content.location: At the right end of the Wall of the Unclimbables, this climb starts below the low-angled right-leaning groove below and the bright green face above.

content.description: Climb hollow sounding rock to the first high bolt. Continue on overhanging jugs to a short crack and a nice ledge.  Then ascend a thin crack to the bolt anchors.
content.protection: 1 bolt, SR, maybe a crash pad due to so-so rock before a high bolt
content.location: Leftmost route on the Last Chance Wall, 15 feet or so left of Last Chance itself.

content.description: Climb the hand to fist sized dihedral crack over a few small bulges to the anchors.  This is a popular climb for newer leaders.  Good rock.
content.protection: Gear to 3.5".  No more bolted anchor, as the block the bolts were in fell off.  Save the trees, it's a short walk back over to the Dog Walkdown.
content.location: In the middle of the Wall of the Unclimbables area, this is the large left faciung dihedral with jugs all over.  This line is just left around the corner from the first open area you see in the Outback, where you see Water into Wine.

content.description: Starting right of the crack, climb up to the first bolt.  Then, traverse left to the second bolt.  From there, head up through the roof via the crack.  Above, climb the lower-angled rock to the finger crack.  Climb this up and over a small bulge to the anchors.  Mostly good rock.
content.protection: 2 bolts, gear to 3".  2-bolt anchor.  Rap or lower.
content.location: This is the left of the two steep cracks running through the middle of the Wall of the Unclimbables.  Start right of the crack.

content.description: Climb the right angling dihedral crack past a few small steeper sections and bulges.  Good rock.
content.protection: Pro to 3".  Don't remember if there were bolted anchors.  If not, rap off trees.
content.location: Near the right end of the Wall of the Unclimbables area, this route is in the right end of the first open area you see, where Water into Wine is located.  It is the right facing, right angling dihedral.

content.description: Climb the awesome dike system that angles up and left in an almost perfect straight line.  At the bulge, climb straight up over, clip the last bolt, then angle back up and right to the anchors.  The climbing to the anchors is a little run-out, but shouldn't be the crux.
content.location: This is the sport route just left of Dog Day Afternoon.

content.description:
This route has more history than Cher and Meatloaf! 

  No, not really; but it sure has given me a couple stories to tell. 

  Here's one:   The first day I went to do this it was an early morning and I was alone. I started from the ground, rope soloing. The wind was HOWLING. I am not good on measuring wind speed, but surely it was over 300 miles an hour. Maybe more. 

  Up through the 5.8 section of good handcrack and jugs to the obvious break, and the blank headwall. I placed a bolt, and lightened the load. I tried to free to the next break and took a number of wingers. Finally, I figured out the sequence, using a key crimp and nailed the crux. I climbed above it a little bit and placed a hook, then pulled up my drill. After another bolt, I pulled up rope to clip in. And then...   POP GOES THE WEASEL! with all my slack out to clip and my drill over my shoulder I took the big ride. 

  I screamed like a little girl.   No, literally, it was full falsetto, and a little nasaly. 

  The key crimp?  

  Gone. 

  Good luck.
content.location: Start on the low angle, winding crack, 30 feet left of "Last Chance" then pull onto blank face, and then to steep "crack" at the top. Belay/Rap at a tree

content.description: Climb the low-angled face below the roof, through a shallow dihedral with a bolt, and to the roof under the crack.  Clip the bolt at the base of the crack and jam up through the hands and fists, pulling up onto a ledge.  From there, head up and right, into and past a dihedral system, heading for the bolts on the right.  Great rock, except the first part to the roof.  That rock is only decent.
content.protection: 2 bolts, gear to 3.5".  Shares 2-bolt anchor with Water into Wine on the Left.  Rap only.
content.location: This is the right of the two steep cracks cutting a bulge halfway up.

content.description: This is the first area encountered in the Outback.  Steep and shady, this area also has really good rock and very fun climbs.
